{{short description|2013 single by Justin Timberlake}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2019}} {{Infobox song | name = Mirrors | cover = JTMirrorsCover.png | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Justin Timberlake]] | album = [[The 20/20 Experience]] | B-side = "[[Suit & Tie]]" {{small|(CD)}} | released = {{Start date|2013|02|11}} | format = {{hlist|[[CD single|CD]]|[[Music download|digital download]]}} | recorded = June 2012 | studio = Larrabee Studios ([[North Hollywood, Los Angeles|North Hollywood]]) | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Pop music|Pop]]|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]}} | length = {{ubl|{{Duration|m=8|s=05}} {{small|(album version)}}|{{Duration|m=4|s=37}} {{small|(radio edit)}}}} | label = [[RCA Records|RCA]] | writer = {{hlist|Justin Timberlake|[[Timbaland|Timothy Mosley]]|[[Jerome Harmon]]|[[James Fauntleroy]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[J-Roc (record producer)|J-Roc]]|[[Timbaland]]|Justin Timberlake}} | prev_title = [[Suit & Tie]] | prev_year = 2013 | next_title = [[Tunnel Vision (Justin Timberlake song)|Tunnel Vision]] | next_year = 2013 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|uuZE_IRwLNI|"Mirrors"}}}} }} "'''Mirrors'''" is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake]] for his third [[studio album]], ''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'' (2013). First conceived in 2009, the track was inspired by his relationship to [[Jessica Biel]] and the marriage of his grandparents. It is an eight-minute-long mid-tempo [[Pop music|Pop]] and [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] [[Ballad (music)|ballad]]. Timberlake wrote and produced the song with [[Timbaland|Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley]] and [[J-Roc (record producer)|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]], with additional writing from [[James Fauntleroy]]. The accompanying music video, directed by [[Floria Sigismondi]], was released in March 2013 and depicts a tale of two lovers through several decades. "Mirrors" was issued as the second single from ''The 20/20 Experience'' in February 2013. It went on to top the Australian Urban, Bulgarian, European, Lebanese, Polish, South African and United Kingdom singles charts, being Timberlake's fourth number-one single in the latter. It peaked at number two on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and topped the [[Mainstream Top 40]] in the United States. "Mirrors" was ranked at number six on the [[Billboard Year-End Hot 100 singles of 2013|Year-End Hot 100]] chart. The song was met with positive reviews by critics upon release and received a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Solo Performance|Best Pop Solo Performance]]. Its music video won two [[MTV Video Music Awards]] including [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]]. As of 2018, the song has sold over 3.9 million downloads in the US. Timberlake performed "Mirrors" on television shows including ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' and the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]] as part of a medley number. It was included on [[Legends of the Summer Tour]] and [[The 20/20 Experience World Tour]] [[setlist]]s. The [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers]] (ASCAP) recognized it as one of the most performed songs of 2014 and 2015. ==Production and writing== "Mirrors" was written and produced by Justin Timberlake, [[Timbaland|Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley]] and [[Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]], with additional writing from [[James Fauntleroy]]. During an interview with ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine, Harmon recalled how the song was conceived in 2009, during the recording sessions for Timbaland's third studio album ''[[Shock Value II]]'' (2009), "He's [Timberlake] like, 'I'm gonna save this one, and this is gonna go on my album.' We never knew when he was going to put it out – we were like, 'Aw man, you're in movies now!' We could have waited another 10, 15 years. But then he surprised us last year and said he was ready, and he brought ['Mirrors'] over to the project as well."{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/1558428/justin-timberlakes-november-album-to-feature-material-from-2020 |title=Justin Timberlake's November Album To Feature Material From '20/20' Sessions |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=April 17, 2013 |last=Lipshutz|first=Jason|accessdate=June 17, 2013}} Although the final version of "Mirrors" is eight minutes long, Harmon stated that the more [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] oriented second half (in contrast with the [[Rock music|rock]]-influenced first half) was made years later and independent of the original track, "We segued each piece to go into another song, so if you were to break it up, that second part of 'Mirrors' is like a song by itself. Once we got all the songs that [Timberlake] knew he wanted on this album, then that's when we began to tie everything together, and the second part just fell in order." "Mirrors" was [[Engineering (music)|engineered]] by Chris Godbey, with assistance from Alejandro Baima. Timberlake arranged and produced his vocals, which were recorded at Larabee Studios in [[North Hollywood]], California. The song was [[Mixing (music production)|mixed]] by Jimmy Douglass, Godbey and Timberlake at Larabee Studios. Harmon provided [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]] for the song, while Elliot Ives played the [[guitar]]. The strings in the song were played by [[Benjamin Wright (composer)|Benjamin Wright]] and The Benjamin Wright Orchestra. In his book ''[[Hindsight (book)|Hindsight]]'' (2018) Timberlake elaborated about writing the song for his wife [[Jessica Biel]], "We were living together at the time. We weren't engaged yet. In fact, it was years before I proposed... The video became a dedication to my grandparents. I learned about long-lasting love from them. I know that’s what I have with my wife... She changed me. She changed my life. All of that is in "Mirrors." Not the details. But the way it felt to have my life be touched by her..."{{Cite news |url=https://ew.com/books/2018/10/29/justin-timberlake-hindsight-excerpt/ |title=Justin Timberlake writes how Jessica Biel changed his life |last=Canfield |first=David |date=October 29, 2018 |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=November 10, 2018}} == Composition and lyrical interpretation == {{listen | pos = right | filename = Justin Timberlake_-_Mirrors.ogg | title = "Mirrors" (2013) | description = A 29 second sample of "Mirrors". It features [[emo]] [[power ballad]] guitar strobes, [[Hand Clapping|hand-claps]], orchestral [[Flare (scratch)|flares]], electro blips, chipmunk synth chirps accompanied with "vocoder-squawk [[backing vocals]]". | format = [[Ogg]] }} "Mirrors" is a mid-tempo [[progressive pop]]{{cite web | url=http://www.stereogum.com/1570602/deconstructing-justin-timberlake-and-the-dangers-of-overexposure/franchises/deconstructing/ | title=Deconstructing: Justin Timberlake And The Dangers Of Overexposure | publisher=[[Stereogum]] | date=November 19, 2013 | accessdate=April 8, 2016 | author=DeVille, Chris}} and [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2013/03/review-justin-timberlakes-the-2020-experience/|title=Review: Justin Timberlake's 'The 20/20 Experience'|publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Raible|first=Allan|date=March 23, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} [[Ballad (music)|ballad]]{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/mirrors-mw0002501233|title=Mirrors — Justin Timberlake — Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards|website=[[AllMusic]]|last=Kellman|first=Andy|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} with an approximate length of eight minutes and five seconds. It is composed in the key of [[E-flat major|E{{music|flat}} major]], set in [[common time]] and has a moderately slow [[Groove (music)|groove]] of 77 beats per minute. Timberlake's vocals span from the low note of [[E♭ (musical note)|E{{music|flat}}3]] to the high note of [[C (musical note)|C5]] (sheet music commonly prints the notes of a melody an octave higher to keep it within the staff).{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0114036&|title=Justin Timberlake – Mirrors Sheet Music (Digital Download)|publisher=Musicnotes.com. [[Universal Music Publishing Group]]|accessdate=October 16, 2012}} The original mix has an [[Instrumentation (music)|instrumentation]] of [[emo]] [[power ballad]] guitar strobes, [[Hand Clapping|hand-claps]], orchestral [[Flare (scratch)|flares]], electro blips and chipmunk synth chirps accompanied with "vocoder-squawk [[backing vocals]]",{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/songreviews/mirrors-20130222|title=Mirrors — Song Reviews|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|last=Dolan|first=Jon|date=February 22, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} and the orchestra has a noticeable much-lower volume than the percussion and electric guitars.{{cite web|last=Senior|first=Mike|url=http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/nov13/articles/tmr-1113.htm|date=November 2013|title=The Mix Review|work=[[Sound on Sound]]|accessdate=January 22, 2014}} Brad Stern of [[MTV Buzzworthy]] wrote that it is hugely catchy and contains melodies that have arena-size.{{cite web|title=Justin Timberlake 'The 20/20 Experience': Track-By-Track Review... In GIFs!|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2013/03/14/justin-timberlake-2020-experience-review-gifs/|publisher=[[MTV Buzzworthy]]|last=Stern|first=Brad|date=March 14, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'''s Lauren Martin described it as "[[Coldplay]]-does-R&B",{{cite news|url=http://www.factmag.com/2013/03/18/justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience-fact-review/|title=The 20/20 Experience — Fact Magazine: Music News, New Music|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|last=Martin|first=Lauren|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} while according to Raible, "Mirrors" is a sad answer to [[Natalie Imbruglia]]'s 1997 single "[[Torn (Natalie Imbruglia song)|Torn]]". Mikael Wood of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described it as a cross between Timberlake's 2002 single "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]" and "[[November Rain]]" by [[Guns N' Roses]].{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-justin-timberlake-new-song-mirrors-grammy-performance-20130211,0,4356869.story|title=Justin Timberlake releases new song 'Mirrors' after Grammy performance|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|last=Wood|first=Mikael|date=February 11, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} [[HitFix]]'s Melinda Newman wrote that the melody features layer upon layer of the singer's vocals stacked upon each other.{{cite news|url=http://www.hitfix.com/news/justin-timberlakes-the-20-20-experience-album-review|title=Justin Timberlake's 'The 20/20 Experience': Album Review|work=[[HitFix]]|last=Newman|first=Melinda|date=March 15, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} Dolan described Timberlake's singing on the song as "replete with laidback soulfulness, mountain-climbing croon, and [[falsetto]] butter." Jason Lipshutz of ''Billboard'' stated that aside from the presence of Timbaland's "fantastically cluttered production", the difference between "Mirrors" and "Cry Me a River" is clear: "10 years ago, Timberlake was broken, and now he is whole."{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/1551360/justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience-track-by-track-review|title=Justin Timberlake, 'The 20/20 Experience': Track-By-Track Review|work=Billboard|last=Lipshutz|first=Jason|date=March 12, 2013|accessdate=March 13, 2013}} The conclusion can be seen in the opening lyrics:
Aren't you somethin' to admire?
Cause your shine is somethin' like a mirror
And I can't help but notice
You reflect in this heart of mine.
"Mirrors" is a "new-age wedding reception song".{{cite news|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/justin-timberlake-20-20-experience-review-timbaland-are-you-not-entertained|title=Justin Timberlake 'The 20/20 Experience' Review: Are You Not Entertained?|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|last=Hope|first=Clover|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} Lyrically, in the song, Timberlake sings to a lover about "coming to the realization" that she is his "other half".{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1701735/justin-timberlake-grammy-new-song-mirrors-2020-experience.jhtml |title=Justin Timberlake Drops Self-Reflective Song 'Mirrors' After Grammys – Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=[[MTV News]] |date=February 11, 2013 |last=Atkinson|first=Katie|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} The singer references "taking a break from the relationship": "It was easy coming back to you/ Once I figured it out, you were right here all along," he sings on the chorus. "It's like you're my mirror, my mirror staring back at me/ I couldn't get any bigger/ With anyone else beside of me."{{cite web|last=Atkinson |first=Katie |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1701735/justin-timberlake-grammy-new-song-mirrors-2020-experience.jhtml |title=Justin Timberlake Drops Self-Reflective Song 'Mirrors' After Grammys – Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=MTV.com |date= |accessdate=February 11, 2013}} ''Vibe'''s Charley Rogulewski wrote that the strength of the song is in Timberlake's Neo [[blue-eyed soul]] delivery of the "catchy" lyrics, "I don't want to lose you now. I'm looking right at the other half of me."{{cite news|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/justin-timberlake-debuts-8-minute-track-mirrors-listen|title=Justin Timberlake Debuts 8-Minute Track, 'Mirrors' (Listen)|work=Vibe|last=Rogulewski|first=Charley|date=February 11, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} In the full-length version, a robot voice repeats the phrase "you are the love of my life" over 35 times.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/justin-timberlake/14262|title=NME Album Reviews — Justin Timberlake - 'The 20/20 Experience'|work=[[NME]]|last=Rowe|first=Siân|date=April 2, 2013|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} ==Release== On February 11, 2013, "Mirrors" was digitally released worldwide as the second single from his album, ''The 20/20 Experience''. Timberlake had announced the release on his [[Twitter]] account the previous day.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/justin-timberlake-releases-mirrors-grammys-420305 |title=Justin Timberlake Releases 'Mirrors' After Grammys |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=November 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2013}} It was available to buy as either as a stand-alone track or as an "instant-gratification download" when a customer pre-ordered the album.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1549388/baauers-harlem-shake-debuts-atop-revamped-hot-100 |title=Baauer's 'Harlem Shake' Debuts Atop Revamped Hot 100 |magazine=Billboard |date=February 20, 2013 |accessdate=June 17, 2013}} On March 1, it was released in Germany as a [[CD single]], which it also contained the [[lead single]] from the album, "[[Suit & Tie]]". A radio edit of the single, was released for digital download on March 13 in France, Spain and the United States. On April 16, it was solicited to [[Contemporary hit radio|contemporary hit]] and [[Rhythmic contemporary|rhythmic]] radio stations in the United States. Additionally, "Mirrors" was sent to [[Adult Contemporary (radio network)|adult contemporary radio]] on April 22 and to [[urban contemporary]] radio on May 14. ==Critical reception== The song received positive reviews from music critics. Jenna Hally Rubenstein of [[MTV Buzzworthy]] commented in a positive review, "Unlike "Suit & Tie"'s sultry and retro vibes, the selfie-taker's new jam reminds us a bit more of Justin's ''[[FutureSex/LoveSounds]]'' days with layered synths and ridiculously club-ready pop production courtesy of JT's main man Timbaland."{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2013/02/11/justin-timberlake-mirrors/ |title=New Song: Justin Timberlake, 'Mirrors' |publisher=Buzzworthy.mtv.com |date= |accessdate=February 11, 2013}} Scott Shetler of ''Popcrush'' gave the single four stars out of five, writing: "The song relies on Timbaland’s familiar handclap-style beats and layers of synths and vocals, which instantly embed their way into your brain ... over a bed of gentle piano twinkling and a distorted Timbaland vocal loop, JT delivers some falsetto crooning and a heavy dose of “oohs” and “aahs.”"{{cite web|last=Shetler|first=Scott|title=JUSTIN TIMBERLAKE, 'MIRRORS' – SONG REVIEW|url=http://popcrush.com/justin-timberlake-mirrors/|publisher=Popcrush|accessdate=March 5, 2013}} Another favorable review came from [[Digital Spy]]'s Robert Copsey, who wrote: "Despite musical shifts in the intervening 11 years and the absence of a cheating girlfriend, [the single] still manages to sound remarkably fresh. "It's like you're my mirror/ My mirror staring back at me," he tells his lover over head-nodding Timbaland beatboxing and grandiose strings, before spilling his guts about how he should never have left them in the first place."{{cite web|last=Copsey|first=Robert|title=Justin Timberlake: 'Mirrors' – Single review|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/singlesreviews/a460848/justin-timberlake-mirrors-single-review.html|website=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=March 5, 2013|date=2013-02-22}} Emily Exton from [[VH1]] called it "grand and ambitious... It’s an interesting character study and an even more interesting ride, completely changing up the rhythm and arrangement after five minutes,"{{Cite news |url=http://www.vh1.com/news/51659/justin-timberlake-greatest-songs/ |title=Let The Groove Get In: Justin Timberlake's 20 Greatest Songs |date=October 4, 2013 |work=VH1 |access-date=June 21, 2017}} while [[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] staff said, "An eight-minute song doesn’t always materialize into something awesome, but here it actually worked."{{Cite news |url=http://www.idolator.com/7634013/justin-timberlake-nsync-biggest-songs-reviewed-playlist-listen/6 |title=Justin Timberlake's 23 Top 10 Singles (Including *NSYNC!): Revisited, Reviewed & Ranked |date=May 20, 2016 |work=Idolator |access-date=June 21, 2017}} However, Marc Hogan of ''[[Spin Magazine]]'' provided a mixed review, stating "And how does the former [['N Sync]] singer choose to crown his return to pop prominence but with a pickup line even [[MxPx]] wouldn't touch? Backed with music that's a cross between luxe [[Bruno Mars]] '80s-grenade balladry and those human beatbox hiccups that, in all honesty, were starting to be played out even when Timberlake tapped [[Timbaland]] to use them, brilliantly, on ''[[FutureSex/LoveSounds]]''?"{{cite web|last=Hogan |first=Marc |url=https://www.spin.com/2013/02/justin-timberlake-mirrors-20-20-experience/ |title=Hear Justin Timberlake Drop Cheesy Pickup Lines on 'Mirrors' | SPIN | SPIN Mix | Songs |publisher=SPIN |date= 2013-02-11|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} ''[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]'''s Charley Rogulewski wrote that the singer renders the song more like a pop performer than a R&B, and puts a "wider space between him and the likes of [[Robin Thicke]]. This man is making a serious comeback." Andy Kellman of [[Allmusic]] unfavorably described the song as "less an epic than a drawn-out midtempo pop ballad" and "not one of [Timberlake's] more remarkable singles."{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/mirrors-mw0002501233 | title=Mirrors – Justin Timberlake | publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] | accessdate=June 25, 2013}} In a monthly mix review published in ''[[Sound on Sound]]'', Mike Senior was not positive towards the track, feeling that the live strings used in the track were wasted, and sounded too low of volume compared to the other instruments. At the end of the year, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' listed "Mirrors" at number 7 on its list of 100 Best Songs of 2013{{cite web| url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-best-songs-of-2013-20131204/justin-timberlake-mirrors-19691231| title= 100 Best Songs of 2013| work= [[Rolling Stone]]| accessdate=November 30, 2014| date= 2013-12-04}} and ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' editors placed it at number 10 on its 20 Best Songs of 2013.{{cite web| url= http://www.billboard.com/articles/list/5840322/20-best-songs-of-2013-critics-picks?list_page=1| title= Best Songs of 2013: Critics' Picks | work= Billboard| author= Billboard Staff | date=December 18, 2013 | accessdate=November 30, 2014}} == Chart performance == In the US, "Mirrors" debuted at number 24 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart and sold 163,000 copies in its first week.{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-feb-17-2013-songs-harlem-shakes-020629170.html|title=Week Ending Feb. 17, 2013. Songs: 'Harlem Shake' Debuts At #1|publisher=Chart Watch. [[Yahoo! Music]]|last=Grein|first=Paul|date=February 20, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} In its third week the song fell to number 97, however it rebound to 77 in its fourth week on the chart.{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-march-10-2013-songs-record-setter-220555683.html|title=Week Ending March 10, 2013. Songs: The Record-Setter That Isn't #1|publisher=Chart Watch. Yahoo! Music|last=Grein|first=Paul|date=February 20, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} In its sixth week on the chart, the song reached number 13 and for the issue dated June 15, 2013, "Mirrors" reached its peak on the chart at number two, held from the top spot by [[Macklemore and Ryan Lewis]]' "[[Can't Hold Us]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1565745/macklemore-ryan-lewis-still-atop-hot-100-robin-thicke-reaches-top-10|title=Macklemore & Ryan Lewis Still Atop Hot 100, Robin Thicke Reaches Top 10|work=Billboard|last=Trust|first=Gary|date=June 5, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} For the week dated June 1, 2013, the single topped the US [[Mainstream Top 40]] chart and tied Timberlake for most number-ones with singer [[Bruno Mars]]; each of them has six.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1563139/cant-stop-macklemore-ryan-lewis-atop-hot-100|title='Can't' Stop Macklemore & Ryan Lewis Atop Hot 100|work=Billboard|last=Trust|first=Gary|date=May 22, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} The song topped the chart for three consecutive weeks. "Mirrors" also topped the [[Adult Pop Songs]] chart and reached number eight on the [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary]] chart. Additionally, it spent seven weeks atop [[Radio Songs]].{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/archive/charts/2013/radio-songs | title=Radio Songs - 2013 Archive | work=Billboard | accessdate=June 14, 2016}} "Mirrors" became the third song to top the Mainstream Top 40, [[Rhythmic (chart)|Rhythmic]] and Adult Pop Songs airplay charts, tying the record held by [[Mariah Carey]] & [[Boyz II Men]]'s "[[One Sweet Day]]" (1995–1996) and [[Ricky Martin]]'s "[[Livin' La Vida Loca]]" (1999).{{Cite news |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8219354/camila-cabello-havana-adult-pop-songs-chart-number-one-record-rhythmic-adult |title=Camila Cabello's 'Havana' Is First Song by a Woman to Top Pop, Rhythmic & Adult Pop Songs Charts Since 1996 |last=Trust |first=Gary |date=February 26, 2018 |work=Billboard |access-date=February 26, 2018}} It was certified double platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-oct-20-2013-songs-women-charge-203158409.html |title=Week Ending Oct. 20, 2013. Songs: Women In Charge|last=Grein|first=Paul|work=Chart Watch|date=October 23, 2013|accessdate=October 26, 2013}} As of 2018, the song has accumulated 5.9 million units in the US, combining sales (3.9 million downloads sold) and equivalent streams.{{Cite news |url=http://www.nielsen.com/us/en/insights/news/2018/the-evolution-of-super-bowl-lii-halftime-performer-justin-timberlake.html?cid=socSprinklr-Nielsen |title=The Evolution of Super Bowl LII Half-Time Performer Justin Timberlake |date=January 31, 2018 |work=Nielsen |access-date=January 31, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201020357/http://www.nielsen.com/us/en/insights/news/2018/the-evolution-of-super-bowl-lii-halftime-performer-justin-timberlake.html?cid=socSprinklr-Nielsen |archive-date=February 1, 2018 |url-status=dead }}{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8097976/justin-timberlake-nsync-career-album-song-sales-ask-billboard|title=Ask Billboard: Justin Timberlake & *NSYNC's Career Album & Song Sales |work=Billboard |publisher=Billboard-Hollywood Media Group |date=February 4, 2018 |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |last=Trust |first=Gary}} On the Canadian Hot 100, the single reached a peak of number four. "Mirrors" was certified double platinum by [[Music Canada]], selling over 160,000 digital copies in the country. "Mirrors" debuted at number 28 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] on February 23, 2013 and reached number one on March 3, 2013. It became Timberlake's second solo single to top the chart and fourth song overall.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/justin-timberlake-scores-first-number-1-since-sexyback-1888/|title=Justin Timberlake scores first Number 1 since Sexyback|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|last=Kreisler|first=Lauren|date=March 3, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} The single topped the chart for three consecutive weeks.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/justin-timberlake-denies-nicole-scherzinger-a-second-uk-number-1-2115/|title=Justin Timberlake denies Nicole Scherzinger a second UK Number 1|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|last=Kreisler|first=Lauren|date=March 17, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} It also reached number on the [[Scottish Singles and Albums Charts|Scottish Singles Chart]] and number two on the [[Irish Singles Chart]]. "Mirrors" peaked number two on the [[German Singles Chart]]{{cite web|url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/titel-details-2772|title=Mariah Carey –'Without You'|language=German|work=Offizielle Deutsche Charts|publisher=GfK Entertainment|accessdate=December 5, 2018}} and was certified platinum by [[Bundesverband Musikindustrie]] (BMVI) for selling over 300,000 digital copies in the country. The single debuted and peaked at number four on the [[Danish Singles Chart]]; it stayed on the position for two weeks. [[IFPI Denmark]] certified the song platinum for selling over 30,000 copies. In Switzerland, "Mirrors" peaked at number five on the [[Swiss Hitparade|Swiss Singles Chart]] and stayed on its peak for four weeks. The song debuted on the [[Norwegian Singles Chart]] at number 18. In its fourth week, it reach a peak of number seven and stayed on the position for two consecutive weeks. The single debuted on the [[ARIA Charts|Australian Singles Chart]] at number 26 on March 24, 2013. After eight weeks on the chart, it reached its peak of number 10 on May 12, 2013. It also reached number one on the Australian Urban Singles Chart. "Mirrors" was certified double platinum by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) for selling over 140,000 copies in the country. In New Zealand, the song debuted at number 23 on March 4, 2013. After five weeks on the chart, on April 1, 2013, "Mirrors" reached its peak of number seven on the chart and stayed on the position the next week. [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]] (RIANZ) certified it platinum for selling over 15,000 copies in the country. In 2013, "Mirrors" was ranked as the 6th most popular song of the year on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2013/hot-100-songs?page=1|title=Best of 2013 – Hot 100 Songs|magazine=Billboard.com|accessdate=2013-12-13}} == Music video == ===Development=== [[File:Mirrors music video.png|thumb|upright=0.8|Timberlake catching his grandparents' wedding ring, before embarking on a "lengthy, and quite wrought" dance sequence. An ''[[MTV News]]'' writer thought the scene is a reference to the time his grandfather's failing health prevented him from attending Timberlake's wedding.]] The music video was directed by [[Floria Sigismondi]]{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/1552553/justin-timberlake-reflects-in-lengthy-new-mirrors-clip | title=Justin Timberlake Reflects In Lengthy New 'Mirrors' Clip | work=Billboard | date=March 20, 2013 | accessdate=April 25, 2016}} and saw its world premiere as the highlight of an hour-long special on [[The CW Television Network|The CW]] in celebration of ''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'''s release.[http://www.cinemablend.com/pop/Watch-Justin-Timberlake-Mirrors-Music-Video-Tells-Love-Story-53828.html] Retrieved March 20, 2013. Timberlake dedicated the music video to his maternal grandparents William and Sadie Bomar, who were married for 63 years until William's death in 2012. The video is choreographed by Noemie Lafrance. It features montages of three separate time periods of a couple's life, from their initial introduction and whimsically falling in love on a [[funhouse]] date (portrayed by actors [[Ariane Rinehart]] and Keenan Cochrane), to the difficult start of their marriage with a pregnancy (portrayed by Chloe Brooks and James Kacey), to when they have grown old together and the old lady ([[Judith Roberts (actress)|Judith Roberts]]) packing up her recently deceased husband's belonging whilst reflecting on their life together. At the beginning, the elderly woman looks back on her teen years in the 1950s when she meets her husband in a bar and goes on a date to a [[funhouse]]. Then, in the 1960s, she cries with black mascara all over her face as she is pregnant and they are unmarried. Meanwhile, the elderly woman, who sees the events of her teen years and interspersed with scenes of her and her husband dancing for the last time before they move out, walks into a mysterious room where an old man is seen staring at the real life woman in her white wedding dress next to two mannequin people while rain pours down on the glass. This is probably symbolizing that he always viewed his wife as beautiful as the day they married. She moves through the video while the old man and the elderly woman move walk through separate ways through the video and through the mirrors symbolizing his death and her moving on. During the final chorus, one of the books the teenaged couple left on the floor of the funhouse falls back into the elderly woman's hand as she closes the book. The old woman is then seen with a ring which is revealed in flashbacks to be her wedding ring, after she married her husband due to the pregnancy. Her husband looks on and they move through separate areas before the end of the video where the old man and woman walk through three versions of mirrors. The elderly woman drops the ring, showing she is ready to move on after her husband's death. This transitions into Timberlake catching it, symbolizing that he is carrying on their legacy. He then sings "you are the love of my life" while dancing through and around the funhouse mirrors. Eventually he is joined by two female dancers in blue wigs. Justin and one of the other dancers eventually mirror each other's movements through glass at the end of the video. ===Reception=== ''MTV News''' James Montgomery reviewed the video, saying:
"It's a clip that packs an emotional wallop, a downright beautiful examination of the ebbs and flows of love and the true connection that continues once our time here is over. That's a rare thing indeed, and so is this video ... it is understated and elegant and really truly touching."{{cite web |url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1704004/justin-timberlake-mirrors-music-video.jhtml |title = Justin Timberlake Premieres Emotional 'Mirrors' Video|author =James Montgomery |publisher =MTV News |date =March 19, 2013 |accessdate =March 19, 2013}}
Timberlake's grandmother Sadie Bomar told Italian weekly ''[[Grazia]]'' that "Justin didn't tell me he was doing it [making the video], it was a surprise. He said, “You have to see this video, just you sit down and watch it". I was moved by it, it brings tears to my eyes. It's a lovely tribute to us."{{cite web |url = http://www.graziadaily.co.uk/conversation/entertainment/exclusive-justin-timberlake-s-granny-on-that-mirrors-video--it-brings-tears-to-my-eyes |title= EXCLUSIVE! Justin Timberlake's Granny On That Mirrors Video: 'It Brings Tears To My Eyes' |author = Lottie Lumsden |date=April 2, 2013}} Timberlake took home the award for [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] at the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]]. The video also won the award for [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Editing|Best Editing]]. It was named one of the 10 best music videos of the year by ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/miley-cyrus-beyonce-justin-timberlake-668275 | title=Best of 2013: 10 Top Music Videos of the Year | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=January 3, 2014 | accessdate=May 31, 2016}} and ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''.{{cite web | url=http://www.spin.com/2013/12/best-music-videos-2013/l9525h2fhkmmei6ga6ioog0k86e/ | title=SPIN's Best Music Videos of 2013 | work=Spin | date=December 23, 2013 | accessdate=May 31, 2016}} Maura Johnston from ''Spin'' wrote: {{quote|"The love scenes between the elder version of the couple are particularly touching; when it's eventually revealed that they've been happening only in the woman’s mind, they become heartbreaking. Plus, there's some fine JT dance moves: Wearing a long coat, silver-tipped shoes, and a severe side part, he shows off his footwork in a hall of mirrors, creating an illusion of endless Justins."}} The music video on YouTube has received more than 600 million views as of January 2020.{{Citation|last=justintimberlakeVEVO|title=Justin Timberlake - Mirrors|date=May 16, 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uuZE_IRwLNI|accessdate=April 6, 2018}} == Live performances == "Mirrors" was performed on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' and ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.
